docs.snippet: 10 P.M. (Showtime) THE TEMPEST (2010) Prospera (Helen Mirren, above), a vengeful sorceress, unleashes her powers against shipwrecked enemies in this adaptation of Shakespeare's drama by Julie Taymor, the director of the ''The Lion King'' on Broadw...
docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Showtime) THE TEMPEST (2010) Prospera (Helen Mirren, above), a vengeful sorceress, unleashes her powers against shipwrecked enemies in this adaptation of Shakespeare's drama by Julie Taymor, the director of the ''The Lion King'' on Broadway and the former director of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.'' Felicity Jones plays Miranda, Prospera's doted-on daughter; Djimon Hounsou is the slave Caliban; and Ben Whishaw is Ariel, the puckish spirit. Alan Cumming, as the treacherous Sebastian, and Chris Cooper, as Antonio, round out the ensemble; Tom Conti is the kindly Gonzalo; David Strathairn is King Alonso; and Russell Brand and Alfred Molina are servants driven by drink and idleness to absurd visions of sovereignty. ''In this noisy, stormy adaptation, an energetic and for the most part excellent cast marshals considerable resources of wit, discipline and timing in a struggle against the hectic inventiveness that is, characteristically for Ms. Taymor, either the vehicle for interesting theatrical ideas or a sign of their absence,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But rather than cohere into a compellingly new -- or satisfyingly traditional -- rendering of the play, they slosh around, generating glimmers of insight, slivers of feeling and spasms of sensation, as well as empty dazzle and frustration.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Hendrik Hertzberg, a senior editor and staff writer at The New Yorker, concludes his discussion of the 2012 campaign by suggesting that the United States elect its president by popular vote.

docs.snippet: An Oscar-nominated film explores the real-life Hollywood drama of Dolores Hart, the recipient of Elvis Presley’s first on-screen kiss, who gave up acting to become a nun....
docs.lead_paragraph: An Oscar-nominated film explores the real-life Hollywood drama of Dolores Hart, the recipient of Elvis Presley’s first on-screen kiss, who gave up acting to become a nun.
docs.abstract: Academy award nominated short documentary God Is the Bigger Elvis, directed by Rebecca Cammisa, tells the story of Dolores Hart, who walked away from a blossoming movie career to become a Benedictine nun at an abbey in Bethlehem, Conn (Metropolitan/Connecticut).

headline.seo: A Preview of ‘God Is the Bigger Elvis,’ Starring Dolores Hart
headline.main: A Nun Returns to the Red Carpet
headline.print_headline: A Nun Returns To the Red Carpet
